title-group.article-title: Prevalence and Associated Factors of Acute Diarrheal Diseases among Children aged 1–5 years Residing in the Amritsar District

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Worldwide, diarrheal diseases claim approximately 1.3 million lives annually among children under 5, making them the second leading cause of childhood mortality globally. According to the National Family Health Survey-5 (NFHS-5), diarrhea affects 7.3% of children under 5 years of age in India, while in Punjab, this figure stands at 4.9%.

sec.title: Materials and Methods:
sec.p: The present cross-sectional study was conducted in rural and urban areas of the Amritsar district from January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023 among children aged 1–5 years. A total of 430 study participants, aged between 1 and 5 years, were included in the sample, with equal urban–rural representation (215 each). The sample was selected from the most populous village and urban slum.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The prevalence of acute diarrheal disease (ADD) over the past 3 months was found to be 23%. ADD was associated with the age of the study participants, the education level of the mother, fast food consumption, immunization status, and water storage practices.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Urban participants experienced a higher prevalence (35%) compared to rural participants (11%). The prevalence of ADD was approximately 3 times higher in the urban slum population in comparison to the rural population.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Each year, India welcomes approximately 25 million newborns, a number comparable to Australia’s entire population.[1] This substantial annual increase in the country’s young population necessitates careful monitoring of children’s health and illness patterns. Global statistics paint a stark picture of diarrheal disease impact on young children. Annually, an estimated 1.7 billion diarrheal episodes occur in this age group, resulting in 123 million clinic visits and 9 million hospitalizations worldwide. The burden of these illnesses translates to a loss of 62 million disability-adjusted life years (DALYs). In India specifically, the situation is particularly grave, with acute diarrheal disease (ADD) responsible for approximately 10% of all deaths among children U-5 years old.[2] Contaminated food and water sources are the main reasons behind diarrheal diseases, which remain the leading cause of morbidity and mortality among children worldwide.[2] A staggering number of people globally face water and sanitation challenges: 780 million individuals do not have access to clean drinking water, and 2.5 billion lack proper sanitation facilities.[3] Infection-induced diarrhea is pervasive throughout developing nations. In low-income nations, children U-3 years of age typically endure an average of three diarrheal episodes annually. Each occurrence robs the child of vital nutrients essential for growth. A destructive feedback loop exists: Diarrhea significantly contributes to malnutrition, while children suffering from malnutrition are more vulnerable to diarrheal diseases.[2] Malnutrition and diarrhea form a dangerous cycle in young children. Malnourished children are more susceptible to diarrheal diseases, and each bout of diarrhea further worsens their nutritional status. As a result, diarrhea is a primary contributor to malnutrition among children under 5 years of age.[4] The prevalence of ADD ranged from 22% to 26.4%, which was reported by various studies conducted in different parts of the country.[567] No such study has been conducted in recent past in our region; therefore, we planned to conduct this study to assess the prevalence of ADD among U-5 children in the past 3 months and to determine the various factor associated with them.

sec.title: MATERIALS AND METHODS
sec.p: The present study is a cross-sectional study conducted for a period of 1 year (01 / 01/2023 to 31 / 12/2023). The Rural Field Practice area of GMC, Amritsar, comprises three villages, namely, Nag Kalan (population =6106), Nangal Pannuan (population =2040), and Nag Nawain (population =1565). For selection of three slums in the urban area, a list of slums both registered and unregistered ones, was procured from the Civil Surgeon office and selection was made by the lottery method. The sequence of the study was from the largest to the smallest of the three villages and three slums.

sec.title: Sample size and sampling technique
sec.p: The sample size was calculated using the formula for a single proportion N > Z2 x P x Q/D2, considering a 95% confidence interval, a 4.9% prevalence of ADD,[8] and 0.05 precision, resulting in an initial size of 71. Therefore, a total of overall 426 study participants formulated the sample size where equal numbers of study participants were included from all the six selected areas, that is, 71 each from three villages and 71 each from three selected urban slums (71 × 6 = 426). There was one child aged 1–5 years (the youngest if the family has a higher number of such children) from every second house with at least one eligible child in all the three villages of the rural field practice area of GMC, Amritsar, and three selected urban slums of Amritsar city. A sample of 430 children, 215 each in rural–urban areas was drawn (four study participants, two each from the largest slum and village were included to get an even distribution of 215 each instead of 213).

sec.title: Data collection tool
sec.p: Prior information to the either of the parents of the child was given, and the purpose of the study was explained to them accordingly. One-to-one interview with parents/informant was held by the author for recording the information as per predesigned, prestructured, and pretested proforma.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: Besides approval from the Institutional Ethical Committee, permission from Civil Surgeon Amritsar was also sought after explaining the purpose of study in depth. The rural part of the study was conducted in the descending order of population at all the three villages falling under the rural field practice area of GMC, Amritsar, while the urban component was conducted in the selected three urban slums arranged in descending order of population of the city. For selection of three slums in the urban area, the list of slums, both registered and unregistered ones, was procured from the Civil Surgeon office and selection was made by the lottery method. The sequence of the study was from the largest to the smallest of the three villages/selected slums. In case, the child of the selected house was suffering from some chronic disease or congenital anomaly or some serious illness or was not available even on the third consecutive visit or the parents did not give the written informed consent, the child from the next house was taken for the study. In case, the family had more than one eligible child, the youngest was selected for the study. Two visits were made per week, and 7–10 children were studied during each visit. The study continued till the required number of children, that is, 215 from rural and urban areas each, were studied.

sec.title: Measurement of weight
sec.p: The weight of the child in the minimal light clothing was recorded accurately on an electronic-type weighing machine. The weighing scale with a minimum unit of 100 g was used, and it was checked and corrected before every use. The weight of every child was measured thrice, and the mean of the three readings was taken as the weight of the child and recorded on the proforma.

sec.title: Measurement of height
sec.p: The height of the children was measured in erect posture by making the child with bare feet to stand on an even ground near a wall with the back of the heels, buttocks, shoulders, and occiput of the child touching the wall. A hard board or scale was placed on the head of the child, and the wall was marked at the level of the scale or board with a soft pencil.
The distance between the ground and the mark on the wall was taken as the height of the child and recorded on the proforma.

sec.title: Measurement of MUAC
sec.p: For measurement of MUAC, Shakir tape was used. Measurement was performed on the left arm or nondominating arm, midway between the acromion and the olecranon. The tape was held gently without pressing the soft tissues. The tape was flexible and nonstretchable and unaffected by temperatures.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Compilation was done using Microsoft Excel, and analysis was done using Epi-info 0.7 (CDC USA). Frequencies and proportions were calculated for nominal/ordinal and categorical variables. The association of binary outcome variables (yes/no), that is, occurrence of diarrhea in the past 3 months, was assessed by using Chi square test with other variables, where P value < 0.05 was considered to be statistically significant.

sec.title: Sociodemographic characteristics
sec.p: Overall, 43% of the study participants were from the age group of 12–24 months and the least were from the age group of 49–60 months (12%). As far as sex of the study participant was concerned, 54% were males and 46% were females.

The overall literacy rate of the mother and father of the study participants was 90% and 88%, respectively. 96% of the mothers were housewives, whereas 71% of the fathers were skilled or unskilled laborers. One rural study participant has lost his father, and one rural study participant has lost her mother.
Only 3% belong to the upper class. Among the rural study participants, the majority, that is, 48%, belong to lower middle socioeconomic status.

sec.title: Prevalence of ADD
sec.p: With regard to prevalence of acute diarrheal disease episode in the past 3 months, the overall prevalence was found to be 23%, but it was significantly higher among the urban population (35%) in comparison to rural (11%) [Table 1].

sec.title: ADD and its associated factors
sec.p: 32% of the children age between 12 and 24 months reported the occurrence of diarrheal episodes in the past 3 months, whereas a significantly lower proportion from the age group of 49–60 months (18%) suffered from the same [Table 2]. The educational status of the mother was found to be significantly associated with ADD, but 36% and 24% of the study participants with illiterate mothers and fathers reported to have ADD, respectively. The prevalence of ADD was relatively higher among those whose mothers were housewives (24%) in comparison to working mothers (17%). The prevalence of the diarrhea was found to be slightly higher among the study participants who fathers were the laborers (24%) in comparison to salaried (22%). Surprisingly, the prevalence of diarrhea increased with an increase in socioeconomic status, where it was as high as 43% among the upper class and 18% among the study participants belonging to the lower class [Table 3].

sec.p: A relatively higher proportion (25%) of study participants who were taking ≥3 meals in a day reported to have had ADD in comparison to 19% among those who took ≤2 meals in a day. Fast food consumption was found to be significantly associated with occurrence of diarrhea, where surprisingly, the prevalence of diarrhea was lower among those who consumed fast foods in comparison to those who did not [Table 4].

sec.p: As far as the association between the environment of the house with ADD was concerned, a slightly higher proportion of study participants residing in pucca houses (24%) and whose water supply was from the tap (25%) reported to have suffered from ADD in comparison to 20% among those residing in kuccha houses and 17% who had water supply from other sources (17%), except for tap water. Purification of drinking water was not found to be associated with ADD, but storage of water was found to be associated with it, where ADD episodes were significantly higher among the study participants where water was stored in a covered container (26%) in comparison to those where water was stored in earthen pots or camphor (14%). The prevalence of diarrhea was relatively higher among the study participants who had no pets or cattle (24%).

The prevalence of ADD was found to be relatively higher among the stunted (height for age <2 SD) (25%) and underweight (weight for age <2 SD) (24%) and among those who had MUAC <12.5 cm (24%) in comparison to those who were normal according to height for age (22%) and weight for age (23%) as well as who had MUAC >12.5 cm (23%), but this difference was not found to be statistically significant.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The prevalence of acute diarrheal disease over the past 3 months was found to be 23%. Urban participants experienced a higher prevalence (35%) compared to rural participants (11%). According to NFHS-5, the overall prevalence of acute diarrheal diseases was 4.9% and the prevalence of acute diarrheal diseases was relatively higher in the urban population (6%) compared to the rural population (4.3%).[8] In contrast, a study by Ilukor Geresom et al.[9] (2019) reported that the prevalence of diarrheal diseases was relatively higher among the rural population (59.8%) compared to urban (42.6%), but in our study, the variation could be attributed to the fact that the urban study participants were from urban slums, which have inadequate infrastructure and poor water and sanitation facilities. According to a study conducted by Koustav Ghosh et al.,[10] the national prevalence of diarrhea was 9.2%. Another study by Pintu Paul found that in India, about 9% of under-5 children experienced diarrheal disease.[11] A study conducted by Sudipta Basa suggested that the prevalence of diarrhea was 14.8% among U-5 children in urban slums of Delhi.[12]

A significant difference in diarrheal occurrences between younger and older children was found. A higher proportion (32%) of children aged 12–24 months experienced diarrheal episodes in the past 3 months compared to only 18% in the 49–60-month age group. Possible reasons for this age-related disparity include developing immune systems in younger children and increased exposure to pathogens as toddlers become more mobile and explore their environment.

The prevalence of ADD was significantly higher among children whose mothers were illiterate (36%) compared to those with literate mothers (17%). Children of housewives had a higher prevalence of ADD (24%) compared to those of working mothers (17%). In some cases, housewives might not adhere to stringent hygiene practices as strictly as necessary, particularly if they are managing multiple household tasks simultaneously.

Interestingly, the data show that diarrhea prevalence decreases as the socioeconomic status decreases, with the highest rate (43%) observed in the upper class and the lowest rate (18%) in the lower class. Upper-class families might be more likely to recognize and report diarrheal episodes.

Surprisingly, children taking ≥3 meals per day showed a higher ADD prevalence (25%) compared to those taking ≤2 meals (19%). This finding suggests that other factors such as food quality or hygiene might play more significant roles. Surprisingly, fast food consumption was associated with a lower ADD prevalence (15%) compared to those who did not consume fast food (24%). It could be related to confounding factors such as socioeconomic status, food handling practices, or differences in reporting.

sec.title: ADD with immunization status
sec.p: 39% of children with incomplete immunization experienced at least one episode of diarrhea in the past 3 months. In contrast, only 22% of fully immunized children reported diarrheal episodes. The statistical significance of this difference strongly suggests that complete immunization is associated with a reduced risk of diarrheal disease in this population.

Participants residing in a pucca house had a slightly higher prevalence of ADD (24%) compared to those in a kaccha house (20%). Pucca houses might have less natural ventilation, potentially creating a more humid environment that favors pathogen growth. Interestingly, those with tap water supply reported 25% prevalence of ADD, compared to 17% among those with other water sources. Access to tap water might correlate with other factors influencing ADD risk. The prevalence of ADD was higher among participants without pets or cattle (24%). Pet ownership might correlate with other factors influencing ADD risk, such as access to healthcare or better nutrition and hygiene practices.

The prevalence of ADD was slightly higher among children who were stunted (25%), were underweight (24%), and had a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) less than 12.5 cm (24%). In comparison, the prevalence of ADD among children with normal height-for-age (22%), weight-for-age (23%), and MUAC greater than 12.5 cm (23%) was slightly lower. However, these differences were not statistically significant. This suggests that there may be a trend toward higher ADD prevalence in children with poorer nutritional status. A study conducted among U-5 children showed an overall prevalence of diarrhea of 5.5% and a high prevalence of diarrhea (41%) in children who had acute malnutrition (wasting).[13]

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: ADD remains a significant health concern, with a higher prevalence in urban areas (35%) compared to rural areas (11%). Factors contributing to the occurrence of ADD include the age of the children, maternal education, fast food consumption, immunization status, and water storage practices. Conduct community-based educational programs for mothers focusing on hygiene, sanitation, nutrition, and early management of diarrhea. Implement outreach vaccination programs in both rural and urban areas to improve access and coverage.
